Chapter 5, Part 2: The Chapter on the Bodhisattva of Oceanic Wisdom
Good sons!
If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas wish to attain the pure seal samÄdhi, they should cultivate and accumulate purity in bodhi, and distance themselves from all turbid thoughts.
Good sons!
If one is unable to see the pure nature of all dharmas, then one will be defiled by the thirst and love of afflictions.

All dharmas are inconceivable, not created, not performed, pure and tranquil, without dust or defilement, without faults, ultimately pure like the nature of liberation, the dharma realm is indestructible and without discrimination, the nature of reality and the nature of dharmas are without distinction.
All dharmas are empty, without characteristics or aspirations, like the nature of liberation, unobstructed and equal. All dharmas are also like this.
If one is able to observe in this way, this is called being without turbidity.
Good sons!
If bodhisattvas are able to expound such a teaching for sentient beings, it is called 'free from impurities.'
Good man!
If there are bodhisattvas whose minds are free from impurities, then these people will attain the pure seal samÄdhi.
Bodhisattva Ocean Wisdom said:
World-Honored One!
Such a samÄdhi has a very profound meaning, because it cannot be spoken;
It cannot be seen, because it cuts off the dharma of counting;
It is difficult to understand, because it cannot be seen;
It is great wisdom, because it encompasses all dharmas.
All bodhisattvas are completely equal, without defilements or impurities, without any obstructions, without any abode, subtle and difficult to understand, and cannot be compared or described.
Its nature is firm and solid, like a vajra;
It does not arise or cease, is not broken or destroyed, is not bound or fettered, is a great light that is far removed from darkness;
It is inconceivable, without defilements and pure, because it is far removed from greed;
It is free from disputes, because it cultivates kindness;
Because it is beyond coming and going, it is neither perceived nor contemplated;
Because it is equal to space, it is equal to everything.
World-Honored One!
What causes and conditions must one contemplate to attain this samÄdhi?
The Buddha said:
Good man!

It is like a person who wants to fly in the sky and must be well-equipped. Bodhisattvas are also like this. If they want to attain this samÄdhi, they must be well-equipped and equally equip themselves with all dharmas.
Why is this?
Because worldly dharmas obtain their fruits from seeds.
Good man!
All conditioned things have consciousness as their seed, but this samÄdhi has no seed.
Why is this?

Because this samÄdhi is not cognized by the eye consciousness, up to and not cognized by the mind consciousness, it is neither form, nor feeling, nor perception, nor mental formations, nor consciousness. Contemplating all dharmas as universally equal, this is called the Perfectly Enlightened One.
Good man!
It is not because of different characteristics that it is called birth and death, and it is not because of different characteristics that it is called nirvÄá¹‡a.
Good sons!
Following the characteristics of birth and death are the characteristics of nirvÄá¹‡a.
Why is this?
Because the inherent nature of all dharmas is pure. The inherent nature is called no nature. That which has no nature is called the characteristic of no nature.
If there are no characteristics of nature, then it is no-action. Such no-action is the nature of dharmas, without written words. If there are no written words, it is called thusness.
Thusness in the past, present, and future is called the three times. That which is the three times is called empty. Emptiness is no-action. In such no-action, how can there be an actor?
Therefore, no-action is called emptiness.

If there is no action and no agent, one should know that there are no dharmas. If there are no dharmas, there is no seeking and no vow. If there is no seeking and no vow, there are no actions of body, speech, and mind. The absence of actions of body, speech, and mind is called unobstructed. The unobstructed is called non-emergence. Non-emergence, non-extinction, and non-abiding are the characteristics of the unconditioned. The characteristics of the unconditioned are called non-abiding.

Non-abiding means the absence of all created karma. The mind does not abide in form, up to the mind not abiding in mental activities. If the mind does not abide in these four places, it is called non-abiding.

If there is no abiding, then one does not give rise to similar conceit. If there is no such similar conceit, then there is no increase. If there is no increase, then there is no cause. If there is no cause, then there is no discursive thought. The absence of discursive thought is called silence.
Good son!

If one is able to have faith in such profound meanings, one will attain liberation, forever free from inverted afflictions and hindrances. One will then be able to uphold the treasury of the Dharma of all Buddhas of the past, future, and present. One will be a great ship captain, guide, caravan leader, mantra master, and physician, and will be able to make offerings to the Buddhas of the three times. This is called a Buddha's disciple.

Surpassing the deeds of MÄra, one will destroy the hordes of MÄra. Before long, one will attain the pure seal samÄdhi, and will be able to make great and firm preparations, like a ship, to ferry sentient beings across the ocean of birth and death.
World-Honored One!
How are bodhisattvas able to destroy all the companions of MÄra?
The Buddha said:
If bodhisattvas do not seek any dharmas, at that time they will be able to destroy the hordes of MÄra and not seek any causes and conditions for realms.
Good man!
There are four kinds of MÄra:
First, the MÄra of the aggregates;
Second, the MÄra of afflictions;
Third, the MÄra of death;
Fourth, the heavenly demons.
Good man!
If one can contemplate the characteristics of phenomena as illusory, then one can destroy the demon of the aggregates.
If one sees all phenomena as having the characteristic of emptiness, then one can destroy the demon of afflictions.
If one sees all phenomena as unborn and unceasing, then one can destroy the demon of death.
If one eliminates pride, then one destroys the heavenly demon.
Furthermore, good man!

If one knows suffering, one can destroy the demon of the aggregates. If one distances oneself from the accumulation [of karma], one destroys the demon of afflictions. If one realizes cessation, one destroys the demon of death. If one cultivates the path, one destroys the heavenly demon.
Furthermore, good man!

If one sees that all conditioned phenomena are suffering, one destroys the demon of the aggregates. If one sees that all phenomena are truly impermanent, one destroys the demon of afflictions. If one sees that all phenomena are truly without self, one destroys the demon of death. If one sees that all phenomena are the quiescent nirvÄá¹‡a, one can destroy the heavenly demon.
Furthermore, good man!
If a bodhisattva, being free from greed for the body, gives away the body and dedicates it to enlightenment, he can destroy the demon of the aggregates;
When giving, being free from stingy and greedy thoughts, he destroys the demon of afflictions;
If he contemplates that all wealth is impermanent, he can destroy the demon of death;
For the sake of sentient beings, cultivating compassionate giving, he can destroy the demon of the heavens.
Moreover, good man!

If a bodhisattva, not for the view of self, upholds pure precepts, he can destroy the demon of the aggregates; not for the greed of existence, he upholds pure precepts, destroying the demon of afflictions; if he upholds pure precepts in order to be far removed from the faults of birth and death, he can destroy the demon of death; if he is able to give rise to the thought of causing those who violate the precepts to all uphold pure precepts, upholding pure precepts then destroys the demon of the heavens.
Moreover, good man!

If a bodhisattva does not see self-patience and self-cultivation of patience, then he destroys the demon of the aggregates. Not seeing sentient beings who cultivate patience, he destroys the demon of afflictions. Not seeing birth and death, he destroys the demon of death. Not seeing enlightenment, he destroys the demon of MÄra.
Moreover, good man!

If a bodhisattva diligently cultivates vigor, with a tranquil body he destroys the demon of the aggregates. Diligent in vigor, with a tranquil mind he destroys the demon of afflictions. Diligent in vigor, contemplating the non-arising of dharmas, he is able to destroy the demon of death. Diligent in vigor, in order to tame sentient beings and turn them away from birth and death, he destroys the demon of MÄra.
Moreover, good man!

If a bodhisattva does not cultivate concentration for the sake of the five aggregates, he is able to destroy the demon of the aggregates. Not attached to the realms and sense bases, he cultivates concentration and destroys the demon of afflictions. Not attached to the sense bases, he cultivates concentration and is able to destroy the demon of death. All wholesome roots dedicated to enlightenment are able to destroy the demon of MÄra.
Moreover, good man!

If a bodhisattva knows the skillful means of the aggregates and can destroy the demon of the aggregates, knows the skillful means of the elements and destroys the demon of afflictions, knows the skillful means of the sense bases and can destroy the demon of death, using such various skillful means to dedicate to enlightenment can destroy the demon of the heavens.
Moreover, good man!

If a bodhisattva contemplates all dharmas as being the characteristic of emptiness and can destroy the demon of the aggregates, contemplates all dharmas as being signless and destroys the demon of afflictions, contemplates all dharmas as being wishless and can destroy the demon of death, being endowed with these three dharmas and dedicating to enlightenment can destroy the demon of the heavens.
Moreover, good man!

If a bodhisattva contemplates the body and the location of the body without awareness and attachment and can destroy the demon of the aggregates, contemplates sensation and the location of sensation without awareness and attachment and destroys the demon of afflictions, contemplates the mind and the location of the mind without awareness and attachment and can destroy the demon of death, contemplates dharmas and the location of dharmas without awareness and attachment and can destroy the demon of the heavens;
Contemplating in this way, one will never lose the mind of enlightenment, and one will be able to destroy the four demons.
Good sons!
If one is attached to the self, then one increases demonic activities. Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas also know that there is a self and also know that there is no self.
If there is a dharma that is neither with a self nor without a self, then there is no single dharma that increases or decreases. All sentient beings are covered by ignorance.
Therefore, bodhisattvas adorn the unsurpassed Great Vehicle, not for the sake of the self, but in order to give rise to adornment. Having given rise to adornment, they think like this:
'Who adorns the dharma, making it firm and indestructible?
I shall adorn it.

I do not adorn it in order to destroy the self, sentient beings, life, or a person, but in order to destroy sentient beings' attachment to the self, the wrong views of sentient beings, life, a person, and so forth, I practice adornment.

Sentient beings mistakenly see these five aggregates as permanent, blissful, self, and pure. I should expound for them the impermanence, suffering, emptiness, and non-self of these [aggregates], enabling sentient beings to attain true wisdom.
If there are sentient beings whose minds have aspirations and seek, one should know that such people are called attached.

If there is no aspiration or seeking, then there is no attachment. If one is not attached, then one does not deceive. If one does not deceive, then one attains true wisdom, knowing the past, future, and present, and is not attached to the past, future, or present.
Why is it so?
The past has already ended, the future has not yet arrived, and the present does not abide.

If one does not give rise to the notion of attachment to the three times, it is called non-inverted, and it is called the practice of the bodhisattva. One thoroughly understands the practices of all sentient beings. Having understood, one clearly explains karma and its fruits, and also knows the practices of greed, anger, and delusion.

Knowing that there are sentient beings who engage in greed and adorn anger, who engage in anger and adorn greed, who engage in delusion and adorn greed, who engage in greed and adorn delusion, who engage in anger and adorn delusion, who engage in delusion and adorn anger.
Good man!

There are sentient beings who give rise to greed towards form but give rise to anger towards sound. There are also sentient beings who give rise to greed towards sound but give rise to aversion towards form. There are sentient beings who give rise to greed towards smell but give rise to aversion towards taste. There are also sentient beings who give rise to greed towards taste but give rise to aversion towards smell. There are sentient beings who give rise to greed towards touch but give rise to aversion towards dharmas. There are also sentient beings who give rise to greed towards dharmas but give rise to aversion towards touch. There are sentient beings whose greed is weak but whose anger is strong. There are also sentient beings whose greed is strong but whose anger is weak. There are those whose greed is weak but whose delusion is strong, whose delusion is weak but whose greed is strong, whose anger is weak but whose delusion is strong, and whose delusion is weak but whose anger is strong.
Some sentient beings are subdued by form, not by sound, smell, taste, touch, or mental objects;

Some are subdued by sound, not by form, smell, taste, touch, or mental objects;ğŸ”½Some are subdued by smell, not by form, sound, taste, touch, or mental objects;ğŸ”½Some are subdued by taste, not by form, sound, smell, touch, or mental objects;
Some are subdued by touch, not by form, sound, smell, taste, or mental objects;
Some are subdued by mental objects, not by form, sound, smell, taste, or touch.
Moreover, there are sentient beings who are subdued due to the tranquility of the mind, not due to the tranquility of the body.
Some sentient beings are subdued due to the tranquility of the body, not due to the tranquility of the mind.
Some sentient beings are subdued by hearing about impermanence, not by suffering, impurity, or non-self.

Some sentient beings are tamed by hearing about suffering, not by impermanence, impurity, or no-self.ğŸ”½Some sentient beings are tamed by hearing about impurity, not by impermanence, suffering, or no-self.
Some sentient beings are tamed by hearing about no-self, not by impermanence, suffering, impurity, or other such things.
Some sentient beings are tamed by seeing the spiritual powers of the body, not by the knowledge of others' minds.
Some sentient beings are tamed by the knowledge of others' minds, not by spiritual powers.
Good man!

There are sentient beings who diligently cultivate and attain liberation slowly, some who attain liberation quickly with little diligence, some who attain liberation quickly with diligent effort, and some who attain liberation slowly with little diligence.

There are those whose causes are liberation but not conditions of liberation, those whose conditions are liberation but not causes of liberation, those whose causes and conditions are liberation, and those whose causes and conditions are not liberation.
There are sentient beings who attain liberation by contemplating internal phenomena, not by contemplating external phenomena;
there are those who attain liberation by contemplating external phenomena, not by contemplating internal phenomena;
there are those who attain liberation by contemplating both internal and external phenomena, and there are those who attain liberation without contemplating either internal or external phenomena.
There are sentient beings who attain liberation through the practice of pleasure, not through the practice of suffering;
there are those who attain liberation through the practice of suffering, not through the practice of pleasure;
there are those who attain liberation through both the practice of suffering and pleasure;
there are those who attain liberation without either the practice of suffering or pleasure.ğŸ”½There are sentient beings who are subdued through praise, not through blame;
there are those who are subdued through blame, not through praise;
there are those who are subdued through both praise and blame;
there are those who are subdued without either praise or blame.
There are sentient beings who can be tamed through counterintuitive teachings, but not through intuitive teachings;
some can be tamed through intuitive teachings, but not through counterintuitive teachings;
some can be tamed through both counterintuitive and intuitive teachings;
some cannot be tamed through either counterintuitive or intuitive teachings.
There are sentient beings who can be tamed through brief teachings, but not through extensive teachings;
some can be tamed through extensive teachings, but not through brief teachings;
some can be tamed through both brief and extensive teachings;
some cannot be tamed through either brief or extensive teachings.

translated: There are sentient beings who can be tamed through the Four Noble Truths, some through the foundations of mindfulness, some through right effort, some through the bases of supernatural power, some through the five faculties, some through the five powers, some through the seven factors of awakening, and some through the eightfold path.

The conduct of sentient beings is inconceivable, the minds of sentient beings are also inconceivable, the taming of sentient beings is inconceivable, the Dharma doors they enter are inconceivable, and the realms of sentient beings are inconceivable.

ÅšÄriputra!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva has two kinds of power:

If bodhisattvas did not have the power of afflictions, they would not be able to practice together with sentient beings, they would not be able to know where sentient beings practice, and they would also realize the state of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas. ÅšÄriputra!
Like a small poisonous snake that does not need a companion, the one who first gives rise to the mind of enlightenment is also like this.
ÅšÄriputra!

ÅšÄriputra!
It is like a single pill of agada that can destroy great poison;

ÅšÄriputra!

ÅšÄriputra!

ÅšÄriputra!

ÅšÄriputra!

It is like the great physician JÄ«vaka who always says:
'In the world, there is nothing that is not medicine.'

It is like the asura king who, to the utmost of his power, cannot block the path of the sun and moon;

ÅšÄriputra!
It is like the palaces and houses of the gods in the form realm that abide in the sky;
The enlightenment attained by diligent practice bodhisattvas is also like this, abiding in emptiness.
ÅšÄriputra!
It is like empty space that can contain all myriad things, yet this empty space is originally neither increased nor decreased;
Immeasurable Buddha-dharmas are also like this. Although bodhisattvas give rise to the mind and seek them, these Buddha-dharmas are neither increased nor decreased.
ÅšÄriputra!
It is like a person who travels in the sky according to their ability, yet the nature of space is neither increased nor decreased;
Bodhisattvas are also like this. Abiding in the power of faith, they practice the Buddha's wisdom, yet this Buddha's wisdom is neither increased nor decreased.
ÅšÄriputra!
It is like a potter who, before the vessel is completed, does not give it the name of a vessel;
Bodhisattvas' wholesome dharmas are also like this. Before giving rise to the mind, they are also not given the name.
ÅšÄriputra!
It is like a person who has already seen the Wheel-Turning Sage King and then does not seek to see the other minor kings;

ÅšÄriputra!
It is like how various treasures do not emerge from other places, but various treasures must emerge from the great ocean.
ÅšÄriputra!
Among the treasures of the Å›rÄvakas, the Three Jewels are not included, but the Three Jewels must come from the treasure of the bodhisattvas.
ÅšÄriputra!
It is like a crown prince who is not called a king but is not not called a king;
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this, not called a buddha but not not called a buddha.
ÅšÄriputra!
It is like a small treasure that cannot be treated lightly.
Why is this?
Because such a small treasure can accomplish great things and benefit many.
The bodhisattva is also like this, and when first giving rise to the mind, one cannot treat it lightly.
ÅšÄriputra!
I now explain such parables for the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas. If there are bodhisattvas who hear these parables, they will attain peace and joy.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
If one wishes to realize the Buddha Way, one should eliminate doubts and confusion,
And those who diligently cultivate the unsurpassed faithful mind will be able to attain bodhi.
If one cultivates the samÄdhi of the pure mudrÄ, one proclaims that all dharmas are like dreams,
Purifying the mind for immeasurable eons, one is then able to realize the path of right enlightenment.ğŸ”½The path attained by the Buddha is not physical action,
Nor is it the two actions of speech and mind,
The nature of the unconditioned is also thus, therefore it cannot be described with analogies.
The Buddha's path is unobstructed and invisible, not the realm of the eye consciousness like empty space,
Not any of the faculties, and also not the realm of the faculties,
Not characteristics, not aggregates, not sense bases or elements, not the mind, thought, perception, or consciousness,
Not knowledge, not the realm of knowledge, therefore the Buddha's realm is unknowable.
The great compassion of the buddhas is difficult to fathom, immeasurable, boundless, and unobstructed,
Without letters or sounds, inexpressible, therefore none can know the Buddha's realm.
Associate with good friends and listen to the true Dharma,
Having heard it, they will immediately attain great blessings and virtues, And always experience wonderful bliss like the buddhas of the past,
All demons will be unable to find an opportunity, And the faculties will be subdued, dwelling in the practice of bliss,
Able to use skillful means to destroy the four demons, And abide in accordance with the Dharma, practicing in the Buddha's realm.
If one practices this bodhisattva path, One will attain enlightenment and expound it for others,
Able to ferry sentient beings across the ocean of birth and death, And able to destroy all great wrong views,
One will attain the unsurpassed marks and so forth, And accomplish the ten powers and four forms of fearlessness,
Able to know the afflictions and practices of sentient beings, And able to destroy all the paths of existence.
If there are bodhisattvas who diligently practice, They will be able to destroy all afflictions,
Just as fire can burn dry grass and trees, The mind of enlightenment can burn afflictions.
At that time, the World-Honored One again told Ocean Wisdom Bodhisattva:
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who diligently practice vigor can easily attain anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.

Whoever has vigor, that person will possess the perfection of giving, the perfection of morality, the perfection of patience, the perfection of vigor, the perfection of meditation, and the perfection of wisdom, and will be able to benefit themselves and others.
Good man!

Innumerable eons ago, there was a world-honored buddha named Diligent Vigor TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened, Perfect in Knowledge and Conduct, Well-Gone, Knower of the Secular World, Unsurpassed Person, Tamer, Teacher of Gods and Men, Buddha, World-Honored One. Their fragrance was sublime, and when the gods of Akaniá¹£á¹­ha saw it, they experienced much peace and comfort, and said:

Therefore, this eon is called the Flower-Aggregate.

At that time, the country was tranquil and silent. Because of the silence, the bodhisattvas of immeasurable worlds always delighted in observing, and because of the observation, each of them attained the samÄdhi of joyful practice. Therefore, that world was called the Well-Seen.

That country will have many forests of the seven treasures, towers, and palaces. The sentient beings will be as blissful as those in Tuá¹£ita Heaven. There will be plenty of food and drink, and it will be easy to attain spiritual powers. There will be no female bodies, and all will be born through transformation. Furthermore, giving rise means the perfection of generosity and the perfection of morality, practicing means the perfection of patience and the perfection of diligence, observing means the perfection of meditation and the perfection of wisdom, and abiding in the Dharma means the perfection of cognition and the perfection of skillful means.

Furthermore, giving rise means attracting through generosity, practicing means attracting through gentle speech, observing means attracting through benefiting others, and abiding in the Dharma means attracting through sharing the same interests.
Furthermore, giving rise means great kindness, practicing means great compassion, observing means great joy, and abiding in the Dharma means great equanimity.

Furthermore, the one who sets out upholds the true Dharma, the one who practices purifies the field of merit, the one who contemplates adorns the major and minor marks, and the one who abides in accordance with the Dharma tames sentient beings.

Furthermore, the one who sets out truly knows the demon of the aggregates, the one who practices gets rid of the demon of afflictions, the one who contemplates destroys the demon of death, and the one who abides in accordance with the Dharma subdues the demon of the heavens.

Furthermore, the one who sets out is mindfulness of the body, the one who practices is mindfulness of feelings, the one who contemplates is mindfulness of mind, and the one who abides in accordance with the Dharma is mindfulness of dharmas.

Furthermore, the one who sets out clearly knows suffering, the one who practices abandons the accumulation [of causes], the one who contemplates realizes the true cessation, and the one who abides in accordance with the Dharma practices the path.

Furthermore, 'arising' refers to the seven factors of enlightenment, 'action' refers to the eightfold right path, 'contemplation' refers to Å›amatha, and 'abiding in accordance with the Dharma' refers to vipaÅ›yanÄ.

All practices are called 'arising', cultivating all wholesome [activities] is all called 'action', all pure thoughts are called 'contemplation', and knowing all karmic actions is called 'abiding in accordance with the Dharma.'
Good man!
That Buddha further told Firmly Adorned:
'Good man!
Those who diligently cultivate effort will calm their minds. If the mind is calm, that is effort.
If one destroys the body of craving, that is effort;
If one understands the body and mind, that is effort;
Cutting off the self and what belongs to the self, that is effort;ğŸ”½Cutting off all bonds, that is effort;
Destroying the afflictions that obstruct [enlightenment], that is effort.
If one can distance oneself from all obstructions, that is effort;
If one can eliminate the ten kinds of arrogance, that is diligence;
If one can destroy greed and anger, that is diligence.
If one can stay far away from ignorance and the love of existence, that is diligence.
If one cultivates wholesome dharmas without negligence, that is diligence.ğŸ”½If one truly contemplates internal and external sense bases, that is diligence.
If one truly understands the aggregates, sense bases, and elements, that is diligence;
If one's mind is tranquil, that is diligence;
If one destroys doubts, that is diligence.
If one does not discriminate in the three times, that is diligence;
If one contemplates the dharma realm without moving, that is diligence;ğŸ”½If one is not leaking, that is diligence;ğŸ”½If one does not harm, that is diligence;
If one does not give rise to regret, that is diligence;ğŸ”½If one does not seek, that is diligence;
If one does not extinguish, that is diligence;
If one does not act, that is diligence.ğŸ”½If there is no increase or decrease, that is diligence;
No higher or lower, that is diligence;ğŸ”½Not abandoning or clinging, that is diligence;
Not bound or untied, that is diligence;
Not going or coming, that is diligence;ğŸ”½Not arising or ceasing, that is diligence;
Neither heedful nor heedless, that is diligence;
No action or agent, that is diligence;
No darkness or light, that is diligence;
Neither seeing nor not seeing, that is diligence.'
Good man!
When that Buddha spoke this Dharma of diligence, immeasurable Bodhisattvas attained the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.
Good man!
In this assembly, five thousand Bodhisattvas also attained this Dharma of the non-arising of dharmas.
Seven thousand gods and humans gave rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Good man!

At that time, having heard this Dharma, the Bodhisattva Firmly Adorned diligently cultivated and practiced in order to attain such immeasurable Dharma, and attained the lower forbearance. In order to seek the Dharma, he neither sat nor lay down until the end of his life.

Having given up his body, he was reborn in the Brahma world and received the body of a Brahma god. For immeasurable lives, he made offerings to the Buddha and listened to and accepted the true Dharma. In that kalpa, he made offerings to the eighty-four thousand Buddhas and TathÄgatas, listened to and accepted the true Dharma, and diligently practiced.
Good man!
Do you know that the Firmly Adorned of that time was none other thanğŸ”½myself?
It was I myself.
Good man!
Because I have long been endowed with this diligence, I surpassed the great bodhisattvas such as Maitreya and first attained perfect enlightenment.
Therefore, I say:
Whoever has diligence should know that this person has bodhi.
Good man!
Even for me, who diligently practiced with perseverance, it was still difficult to attain supreme perfect enlightenment, let alone for the indolent.
If there are bodhisattvas who can practice with perseverance, such people will be able to benefit themselves and others.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse, saying:
I recall in the past, countless eons ago, during the Flower-Aggregate Eon, there was a Buddha of Diligence,
In the world of Good Observation, water filled everywhere, and eighty-four thousand flowers emerged.
That country was like the Heaven of Satisfaction, abundant in food and drink, with no female bodies,
Not born from parents, but all born through transformation, also no two paths, purely the One Vehicle.
The bodhisattvas of the ten directions, observing the country of Good Observation, received peace and happiness,
Thirty-two thousand renunciant assemblies, immeasurable humans and gods gave rise to bodhicitta.
At that time, that Buddha praised diligence, only speaking for the steadfast bodhisattvas,
If one can arouse the mind and diligently cultivate goodness, focusing the mind and contemplating, abiding in accordance with the Dharma.ğŸ”½At that time, the World-Honored One, for my sake,
Discriminated and extensively explained these four phrases,
Arousing the bodhi mind, practicing in accordance with the Dharma, contemplating and attaining forbearance, abiding in accordance with the Dharma.
If seeking the true Dharma is called initial arousal, teaching in accordance with the Dharma is called action,
Receiving the meaning without error, contemplating well, cultivating forbearance, abiding in accordance with the Dharma.
If diligently practicing giving is the initial arousal, seeking and finding the recipient is called action,
Clearly seeing impermanence, contemplating well, not observing the two characteristics, abiding in accordance with the Dharma.
Seeking wealth in accordance with the Dharma is the initial arousal, maintaining a pure livelihood is called action,
Destroying stingy thoughts, contemplating well, not seeking arrogance, abiding in accordance with the Dharma.
Staying far away from evil precepts is the initial arousal, guarding the precepts without leakage is called action,
Subduing the immoral with good thoughts, pure precepts without arrogance, abiding in the Dharma.
Avoiding harsh speech is the initial arousal, the mind's tranquility is called action,
the mind's tranquility with good thoughts, the tranquility of all dharmas, abiding in the Dharma.
Avoiding harmful thoughts is the initial arousal, cultivating patience is called action,
protecting oneself and others with good thoughts, being patient without arrogance, abiding in the Dharma.
Persuading the angry is the initial arousal, avoiding bad people is called action,
inner and outer tranquility with good thoughts, not clinging to the mind of self, abiding in the Dharma.
Avoiding laziness is the initial arousal, diligently cultivating vigor is called action,
knowing the truth with good thoughts, cultivating the path, abiding in the Dharma.
Initially seeking good dharmas is the initial arousal, seeking and ultimately accomplishing is called action,
With a mind of mindfulness, upholding and contemplating well, not losing the Dharma, abiding in accordance with the Dharma.
Seeking the factors of meditation is the initial arousal, cultivating samÄdhi is called action,
Contemplating well without similar arrogance, abiding in accordance with the Dharma without fault.
A mind of mindfulness and wisdom is the initial arousal, attaining the Dharma gate is called action,
Contemplating well the protection of the true Dharma, abiding in accordance with the Dharma with courageous and vigorous effort.
The initial arousal is the cause of right mindfulness, the action is cultivating skillful means,
Contemplating well the inner Dharma, abiding in accordance with the Dharma after attaining liberation.
The initial arousal is seeking the written characters, the action is penetrating understanding,
Contemplating well the inexpressibility, abiding in accordance with the Dharma, understanding the absence of written characters.
The initial arousal is distancing oneself from bad friends, the action is befriending good friends,
Having heard, contemplate well as heard, do not depart from the Dharma, abide in the Dharma.
Renouncing the world in the Buddha's teachings is the initial arousal, abandoning enmity and intimacy is called action,
Cultivating wholesome dharmas and good contemplation, not following others' intentions, abiding in the Dharma.
Contentment with few desires is called arousal, delighting in tranquility is good contemplation,
Abiding in tranquility and speaking of non-disputation, also cultivating oneself, abiding in the Dharma.
Learning from precepts is the initial arousal, not practicing defiled precepts is called action,
The precept of no precepts is good contemplation, abiding in the precept of wisdom, abiding in the Dharma.
Not speaking of worldly matters is the initial arousal, always delighting in tranquility is called action,
Easy to support and easy to satisfy is good contemplation, contemplating impermanence, abiding in the Dharma.
Delighting in cultivating giving and precepts is the initial arousal, patience and diligence is called action,
Cultivating skillful means and abiding in the Dharma.
Generosity is the initial arousal, gentle speech is called action,
Benefiting sentient beings is good contemplation, benefiting oneself and others is abiding in the Dharma.
Cultivating compassion is called initial arousal, not discriminating the three times is good contemplation,
Purifying one's body and mind for the sake of sentient beings is abiding in the Dharma.
Obtaining the true Dharma is the initial arousal, pure fields of merit are called action,
Adorning one's own body is good contemplation, taming sentient beings is abiding in the Dharma.
Destroying the demon of the aggregates is the initial arousal, leaving behind the demon of afflictions is called action,
Being able to destroy the demon of death is good contemplation, subduing the demon's enemies is abiding in the Dharma.
Cultivating mindfulness of the body is the initial arousal, cultivating mindfulness of feelings is called action,
Cultivating the mind of mindfulness and good contemplation, cultivating the mindfulness of dharmas and abiding in accordance with the Dharma.
Clearly knowing suffering is the initial arousal, distancing oneself from the origination is called action,
Realizing the truth of cessation is good contemplation, cultivating the right path and abiding in accordance with the Dharma.
Cultivating the faculty of faith is the initial arousal, cultivating the powers is called action,
Cultivating mindfulness and samÄdhi is good contemplation, cultivating wisdom and abiding in accordance with the Dharma.
Tranquility of body and mind is the initial arousal, distancing oneself from wrong views is called action,
Contemplating name and form is good contemplation, diligently without regret and abiding in accordance with the Dharma.
Selflessness and the absence of mine is called arousal, unfettered and unliberated is called action,
Contemplating the unmoving nature of dharmas and abiding in accordance with the Dharma.
Distancing oneself from arrogance is the initial arousal, removing greed and anger is called action,
Free from delusion, with love, abiding in the Dharma as it is.ğŸ”½If one can distance oneself from all characteristics,
Destroying all obstacles,ğŸ”½Endowed with the ten powers and four forms of fearlessness,
One can expound the merits and diligently cultivate.ğŸ”½The TathÄgata expounds this practice of diligence,
Ten thousand beings awaken to non-arising,ğŸ”½Five thousand bodhisattvas attain acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas,
Immeasurable humans and gods give rise to bodhicitta.ğŸ”½I, Solid Adornment, am one,
Surpassing in diligence all bodhisattvas,ğŸ”½If one wishes to attain the supreme true path,
One should cultivate diligence as the buddhas of the past did.
At that time, the BrahmÄ Heaven of Cultivating Compassion said to the bodhisattva Ocean Wisdom:
As for the Buddha's teachings, what are called the Buddha's teachings?
The bodhisattva Ocean Wisdom said:
BrahmÄ Heaven!
The Buddha's teachings are called all dharmas, and all dharmas are called the Buddha's teachings.
Just as the nature of the Buddha's teachings is the nature of all phenomena, the nature of all phenomena is the nature of the Buddha's teachings.

The nature of the Buddha's teachings and the nature of all phenomena are without distinction. All phenomena are quiescent, and the Buddha's teachings are also quiescent. All phenomena are empty, and the Buddha's teachings are also empty.
Brahma Heaven!
All phenomena are the twelve links of dependent arising, and enlightenment is also the twelve links of dependent arising.
Brahma Heaven said:
Good man!
Are the Buddha's teachings not beyond the dharmas of the three realms?
Brahma Heaven!
The nature of the three realms and the Buddha's teachings is without distinction. The three realms are equal, and the Buddha's teachings are equal, without two aspects.
Good man!
It is just like space, which has no increase or decrease. The Buddha's teachings are also like this, without increase or decrease, because their nature is emptiness, without higher or lower.
Brahma Heaven!
If good men wish to see the Buddha's teachings, they should contemplate in this way.
Furthermore, Brahma Heaven!
The Buddha's teachings are neither a place nor not a place, neither arising nor ceasing, neither blue, yellow, red, white, variegated, lapis lazuli, nor the color of the realm of space.

They have no form, shape, squareness, roundness, length, or shortness, no characteristics, no characteristics of characteristics, no bondage, and no liberation. Such characteristics are called the Buddha's teachings.

They have no characteristics, no phrases, and no written words. They are pure and tranquil, the meaning of emptiness, the meaning of no characteristics, the meaning of no aggregation, the ultimate meaning of non-arising, and the meaning of awareness.
They cannot be spoken, seen, or observed. This is called the meaning of tranquility.

The meaning of tranquility is the meaning of emptiness. The meaning of emptiness is the meaning of no aggregation. The meaning of no aggregation is the true meaning. The true meaning is the ultimate meaning of non-arising. The ultimate meaning of non-arising is the meaning of non-cessation.
The meaning of non-cessation is the meaning of no place. The meaning of no place is the nature of dharmas.
The nature of dharmas is precisely the Buddha's teachings. This is called the Dharma of learning, the Dharma of arhats, the Dharma of pratyekabuddhas, and the Dharma of buddhas.

Thus, the Buddha's teachings and all other dharmas have no abode, are neither produced nor extinguished, have no form, shape, squareness, roundness, length or shortness, no characteristics of cognition, no ignorance or darkness. All dharmas are equal and without distinction.
Those who seek the Buddha's teachings refer to the Buddha, the Buddha's teachings, and all dharmas.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas sitting under the bodhi tree at the site of enlightenment can clearly and truly know and see.
Why is this?
Because the true Dharma of the buddhas has no abode, and all dharmas also have no abode. The Buddha's teachings cannot be attained, and all dharmas also cannot be attained.
The Buddha's teachings are equal, and all dharmas are also equal.

If there are no causes and conditions, then there are no types of natures. If there are no types of natures, then there is no arising or ceasing. If there is no arising or ceasing, then it is called the truth. One who truly understands is precisely the true nature. Past, future, and present dharmas are precisely the Buddha Dharma.
Why is this?
Because one penetrates the three times without obstruction.

One without obstruction is precisely the wisdom of the Buddha. The wisdom of the Buddha is precisely the eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha. The eighteen distinctive abilities of the Buddha encompass all dharmas. Therefore, all dharmas are precisely the Buddha Dharma. The Buddha Dharma and all dharmas are non-dual and without distinction.
Brahma Heaven said:
Good man!
Do you now clearly see the Buddha Dharma?
Brahma Heaven!
The Buddha Dharma is not form and cannot be seen. How can you say that you clearly see it?
All dharmas are entirely invisible. That which is clearly seen is precisely the Buddha Dharma, without two appearances.
Brahma Heaven said:
Good man!
Why did the TathÄgata say that the Buddha's knowledge and vision knows all dharmas?
BrahmÄ Heaven!
If the TathÄgata's Buddha Dharma had definite characteristics, it could be said to be clearly known and seen.
Good man!
Is the Buddha Dharma non-existent?
BrahmÄ Heaven!
If the Dharma is without definite characteristics, it cannot be said to exist or not exist.
If its characteristics of existence and non-existence cannot be spoken of, how can it be said to be clearly known and seen?
Good man!
How does the TathÄgata speak of the Buddha Dharma?
BrahmÄ Heaven!
It is like speaking of space. The nature of space is truly without definite characteristics. The Buddha Dharma is also like this.
Good man!

The Buddha Dharma is like this, inconceivable. When bodhisattvas first give rise to the mind of enlightenment, hearing such a Dharma, they are neither startled nor frightened. The inconceivable nature of perfect enlightenment is also inconceivable.
BrahmÄ Heaven!
What the Buddha speaks is able to give rise to this bodhi mind, therefore, hearing it one does not give rise to fear.
Brahma Heaven!
If there is attachment, then one gives rise to fear;
If there is no attachment, then one does not give rise to fear;
Those who cherish their bodies and lives give rise to fear, those who do not cherish their bodies and lives have nothing to fear;
Those who have obstacles give rise to fear, those who have no obstacles have nothing to fear;
Those who are attached to self and what belongs to self give rise to fear, those who cut off self and what belongs to self have nothing to fear.
Good man!
What powers do Bodhisattva-MahÄsattvas have that they hear the profound Buddhist teachings and do not give rise to fear?
Brahma Heaven!
There are eight kinds of powers that enable one to hear the profound Buddhist teachings and not give rise to fear.
What are the eight?
First, the power of faith;
Second, the power of good friends;
Third, the power of much learning;
Fourth, the power of good roots;
Fifth, the power of good contemplation;
Sixth, the power of destroying arrogance;
Seventh, the power of great compassion;
Eighth, the power of abiding in accordance with the Dharma.
Brahma Heaven!
If bodhisattvas are endowed with these eight powers, they will not be afraid when hearing the profound teachings.
At that time, the World-Honored One praised Ocean Wisdom Bodhisattva, saying:
Excellent, excellent!
Good man!
You are well able to proclaim the various powers of bodhisattvas.
It is truly as you have said. If bodhisattvas are endowed with these powers, they will not be afraid when hearing the profound Buddha Dharma.
Good man!

All verbal expressions are called sounds. The nature of enlightenment is also inexpressible and invisible. The inexpressible and invisible is called the ultimate truth. The Tathagata clearly knows and sees such inexpressibility, but out of compassion for sentient beings, he proclaims it.

Good man!

The TathÄgata, out of compassion for sentient beings, awakens to the profound Dharma. Having awakened to the profound Dharma, he has no knowledge, no awareness, no mind or mental factors, no sound, no words, and cannot be expressed. For the sake of sentient beings, he speaks of the sequence of words and sounds.
Good son!
It is like empty space, which is not a visible form, cannot be seen, is not an obstruction, and is not a creation.
Good son!
If someone were to skillfully paint a form in the empty space, whether a man, a woman, an elephant, or a horse, would such a person be conceivable?
No, World-Honored One!
Good son!
This is still believable;
The TathÄgata, the World-Honored One, knows what cannot be spoken and is able to expound it. This matter is extremely difficult.
Although he speaks of this inexpressible Dharma, he truly knows that its nature cannot be spoken.
Good son!
If one hears this Dharma and is neither startled nor frightened, one should know that this person has long planted various wholesome roots in the presence of innumerable TathÄgatas.
Good man!

Such a sÅ«tra is inconceivable. If there is a person who can accept, uphold, read, recite, copy, and explain it, this person will be able to accept and uphold the Dharma treasury of all Buddhas and take in the liberation of all sentient beings.
Good man!

If there is a bodhisattva who clearly sees the Buddhas in innumerable worlds, and having seen them, uses the finest seven treasures filling these worlds to offer to the Buddha-World-Honored Ones, would this person's merit be much?
Very much, World-Honored One!
Such merit is difficult to describe with analogies.

It is not as good as a person who protects the true Dharma out of compassion, accepts and upholds this sÅ«tra, reads and recites it, and explains its meaning.

The giving of Dharma surpasses the giving of food.

If a person is able to protect the true Dharma of the Buddha, it is the four means of unification.

second, unification by the gods;

At that time, the World-Honored One then spoke a verse, saying:
If one can protect the Dharma out of compassion, and uphold and widely expound this sÅ«tra,
I say it is one thousandth of a part, like taking a drop from the great ocean.
Knowing kindness and repaying kindness, remembering the TathÄgata, such a person can be trusted to transmit the Dharma treasury,
Making offerings to immeasurable buddhas of the ten directions, in this way one can protect the Buddha's Dharma.

Adorning and cultivating the major and minor marks, this is all due to protecting the true Dharma.

At that time, in the assembly there was a bodhisattva named Meritorious Treasure Light. He immediately rose from his seat, bowed his head in respect, knelt for a long time with palms joined, and addressed the Buddha, saying:
